revisions.rev:
{{Infobox album | Name = 20Ten | Type = [[Studio album]] | Artist = [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] | Cover = prince20ten.jpg | Border = yes | Alt = | Released = July 10, 2010
(see [[#Release history|release history]]) | Recorded = [[Paisley Park Studios]]
([[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]]) | Genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[funk]], [[Rock music|rock]], [[Soul music|soul]] | Length = 39:18 | Label = [[NPG Records|NPG]] | Producer = [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] | Reviews = | Last album = ''[[Lotusflower (album)|Lotusflow3r]]''
(2009) | This album = '''''20Ten'''''
(2010) | Next album = | Misc = }} '''''20Ten''''' is the thirty-fifth [[studio album]] by American musician [[Prince (musician)|Prince]]. It was released on July 10, 2010 by [[NPG Records]] as a free [[covermount]] with the ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' and ''[[Daily Record (Scotland)|Daily Record]]'' in the UK and Ireland,{{cite news |first=Roy |last=Greenslade |title=Mirror and Record to give away Prince album |date=June 29, 2010 |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/greenslade/2010/jun/29/daily-mirror-prince |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=July 9, 2010 | location=London}} and ''[[Het Nieuwsblad]]'' and ''De Gentenaar'' in Belgium.{{cite web|url=http://www.nieuwsblad.be/article/detail.aspx?articleid=UA2S76CE&kanaalid=1371 |title=Prince geeft nieuw album weg via uw krant|work=Het Nieuwsblad}} It was also released on July 22, 2010 with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine in Germany,{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.de/news/article.php?article_file=1277763000.txt&showtopic=The%20Pop%20Life |title=Prince: Neue CD "20Ten" exklusiv im Rolling Stone |work=Rolling Stone}} and ''[[Courrier International]]'' in France.{{cite web|url=http://jeux.courrierinternational.com/albumprince/ |title=Courrier international crÃ©e l'evÃ¨nement|work=Courrier International}}{{Dead link|date=September 2010}} The album was produced, arranged, composed, and performed by Prince at [[Paisley Park Studios]] in [[Minneapolis]], [[Minnesota]]. It is his thirty-third studio album released in the UK.{{cite news |title=Prince throughout the years - timeline of the music legend's career |date=July 6, 2010 |url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2010/07/06/prince-throughout-the-years-timeline-of-the-music-legend-s-career-115875-22385683/ |newspaper=[[Daily Mirror]] |accessdate=July 10, 2010 }} ''20Ten'' contains musical elements of [[funk]], [[Pop music|pop]], [[Rock music|rock]], and [[soul music]].{{cite news |first= |last= |title=Prince: 20TEN - one day left: La Roux, Rio Ferdinand and Scott Mills give their verdict |date=July 7, 2010 |url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/2010/07/08/prince-20ten-one-day-left-la-roux-rio-ferdinand-and-scott-mills-give-their-verdict-115875-22399155/ |newspaper=Daily Mirror |accessdate=July 10, 2010 }} Some names of the tracks from the album were revealed as clues in Prince's song "Cause and Effect" which was released to radio earlier in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.drfunkenberry.com/2010/02/23/mpls-89-3-to-premiere-new-prince-song-this-friday |title=MPLSâ 89.3 To Premiere New Prince Song This Friday |publisher=Drfunkenberry.com |date=2010-02-23 |accessdate=2011-09-01}} ==Release== Prince revealed the name of the album when receiving a [[BET Lifetime Achievement Award|lifetime achievement award]] at the 2010 [[BET Awards]] in June 2010. He stated to the ''Daily Mirror'' that he chose the title because, "I just think it's a year that really matters. These are very trying times."{{Cite news |first=Peter |last=Willis |title=Peter Willis goes inside the star's secret world |date=July 5, 2010 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/latest/2010/07/05/prince-world-exclusive-interview-peter-willis-goes-inside-the-star-s-secret-world-115875-22382552/ |accessdate=July 21, 2010 }} He considered the album a personal diary of the year.{{Cite news |title=Pop idol Prince seeks pied a terre in France |date=July 8, 2010 |agency=[[Reuters]] |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6671R220100708 |accessdate=August 12, 2010 | first=Victoria | last=Bryan}} Prince made arrangements to release ''20Ten'' exclusively as a free CD add-on to European newspapers on July 10, 2010, including the UK's ''Daily Mirror'', Scotland's ''Daily Record'', and Belgium's ''Het Nieuwsblad'', and on July 22, 2010 in France's ''Courrier International'' and the German edition of ''Rolling Stone''. Over 2.5 million copies were distributed by [[Trinity Mirror]], the publisher of the ''Daily Mirror'' and ''Daily Record''. Prince was featured in the publications, to which he granted his first interview in a British newspaper in over 10 years. The issue of the ''Mirror'' cost 65 pence; the album was not available as a [[music download|digital download]] or in retail stores.{{Cite news |first=Helienne |last=Lindvall |title=Prince's war with iTunes plays into the hands of illegal filesharers |date=July 12, 2010 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/musicblog/2010/jul/12/prince-itunes |accessdate=July 12, 2010 | location=London}} Prince stated to the ''Mirror'' that this method of releasing the album was "the best way to go... no charts, no internet piracy and no stress,"{{Cite news |first=Tom |last=Bryant |title=Purple reign |date=July 10, 2010 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2010/07/10/purple-reign-115875-22402175/ |accessdate=July 12, 2010 }} although the album is easily available for illegal download via [[peer-to-peer]] networks.{{Cite news |first=Jared|last=Moya|title=Fans Bypass Prince, Distribute New 20Ten Album Online |date=July 13, 2010 |work=ZeroPaid |url=http://www.zeropaid.com/news/89873/fans-bypass-prince-distribute-new-20ten-album-online/ |accessdate=July 19, 2010 }} The publisher released that sales of the ''Daily Mirror'' increased by 334,000, and sales of ''The Daily Record'' increased by 45,000 copies on the day it included the album.{{Cite news |first=Andre |last=Paine |title=Prince Giveaway Boosts Mirror's Sales |date=July 13, 2010 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/content_display/industry/e3id62c14caef9dce16d67b0a9d88612e10 |accessdate=July 13, 2010 }} Prince released his album ''[[Planet Earth (album)|Planet Earth]]'' in July 2007 under a similar arrangement with the British newspaper ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]''. {{As of|2011|11}}, no plans for a U.S. release have even been announced.{{Cite news |first=Daniel |last=Kreps |title=Prince Preps Funky New Disc '20Ten' |date=June 29, 2010 |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/17386/122641 |accessdate=July 9, 2010 }} On October 8, Prince told French radio station [[Europe 1]] that he was reportedly planning on releasing an updated edition of the album called ''20Ten Deluxe''.{{cite web| last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = New Prince Song Snippet!~ "Rich Friends" Listen Now | work = Dr. Funkenberry.com| publisher = | date = October 8, 2010| url = http://www.drfunkenberry.com/2010/10/08/new-prince-song-snippet-rich-friends-listen-now| doi = | accessdate = }} It has never materialized. ==Reception== {{Album ratings | rev1 = [[Allmusic]] | rev1Score = {{Rating|2.5|5}} | rev2 = ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' | rev2Score = (favorable) | rev3 = [[MusicOMH]] | rev3Score = {{Rating|2|5}} | rev4 = ''[[NME]]'' | rev4Score = (4/10) | rev5 = ''[[Rolling Stone]] Germany'' | rev5Score = (favorable) }} ''20Ten'' received mixed reviews from most music critics. Columnist [[Tony Parsons (British journalist)|Tony Parsons]] reviewed the album for the ''Daily Mirror'', the newspaper marketing the album.{{Cite news |first=Paul |last=Morley |title=Paul Morley on music: Prince |date=July 11, 2010 |newspaper=[[The Observer]] |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/2010/jul/11/paul-morley-on-music-prince |accessdate=July 11, 2010 | location=London}} He wrote that it was "as good as [Prince's] all-time classics like ''[[Purple Rain (album)|Purple Rain]]'' and ''[[1999 (album)|1999]]'' " and that it's "his best record since ''[[Sign o' the Times (album)|Sign o' the Times]]'' 23 years ago."{{Cite news |first=Tony |last=Parsons |authorlink=Tony Parsons (British journalist) |title=Prince - 20TEN the first review: This is his best album for 23 years says Tony Parsons |date=July 7, 2010 |newspaper=Daily Mirror |url=http://www.mirror.co.uk/celebs/news/2010/07/07/prince-20ten-the-first-review-this-is-his-best-album-for-23-years-says-tony-parsons-115875-22386952/ |accessdate=July 8, 2010 }} Joachim Hentschel, writing for the German edition of ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', viewed the album as Prince's best effort since 1992's the ''[[Love Symbol Album]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.de/news/article.php?article_file=1278456060.txt |title= Prince: Was erwartet uns auf "20Ten"? |work=Rolling Stone |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5rMqhc9MV |archivedate=2010-07-20}} Jason Draper of ''[[NME]]'' gave ''20Ten'' a 4/10 rating, stating that while it "has its moments", the album was "no way" his best in 23 years, but likely his best in four years.{{cite web |first=Jason |last=Draper |title=Album Review: Prince, '20Ten' (NPG) |date=July 12, 2010 |publisher=[[NME]] |url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/prince/11437 |accessdate=July 12, 2010 }} [[MusicOMH]] writer Luke Winkie gave it 2 out of 5 stars and described it as "one of the slightest albums the man has ever recorded; fluffy, anti-climatic, and utterly boring".{{cite web |first=Winkie |last=Luke |title=Prince - 20Ten |date=July 12, 2010 |publisher=[[MusicOMH]] |url=http://www.musicomh.com/albums/prince-5_0710.htm |accessdate=July 20, 2010 }} [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[Allmusic]] gave the album 2Â½ out of 5 stars and wrote that its songs feature "enough of a shape to be attractive from a distance, not enough to withstand closer scrutiny... hooks donât sink in, funk jams are stuck in low gear, sensuality only simmers, the rhythms are somewhat stiff, and Princeâs deliberate mining of the past only highlights how heâs stripped the freakiness out of his entire persona".{{cite web |first=Stephen Thomas |last=Erlewine |title=20TEN > Review |date=July 12, 2010 |publisher=[[Allmusic]] |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r1942199/review|pure_url=yes}} |accessdate=July 20, 2010 }} ==Track listing== All songs were written by [[Prince (musician)|Prince]].{{Cite music release notes |Name=20Ten |Type=album |Artist=[[Prince (musician)|Prince]] |Year=2010 |Format=back cover |Publisher=[[NPG Records]] }} # "Compassion" â 3:57 # "Beginning Endlessly" â 5:27 # "Future Soul Song" â 5:08 # "Sticky Like Glue" â 4:46 # "Act of God" â 3:13 # "Lavaux" â 3:03 # "Walk in Sand" â 3:29 # "Sea of Everything" â 3:49 # "Everybody Loves Me" â 4:08 # "Laydown" â 3:07 ([[hidden track]] on track #77; following tracks #10 to #76, each containing 5 or 6 seconds of silence {{cite web| last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = detailed tracklisting of Prince â 20ten at Discogs | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.discogs.com/Prince-20ten/release/2349465| doi = | accessdate = January 6, 2011}} ) ==Personnel== * [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] â all musical performances, except as indicated below * Liv
